description: From Middle English slepen, from Anglian Old English slēpan, a variant of slǣpan, from Proto-West Germanic *slāpan, from Proto-Germanic *slēpaną.

verbs.description: sleep (third-person singular simple present sleeps, present participle sleeping, simple past and past participle slept)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To rest in a state of reduced consciousness.
examples: You should sleep eight hours a day.

entries.meaning: (transitive, reflexive) To achieve or make happen by manner of sleep.
examples: Sleep your way to good health.
He hoped to sleep his troubles away.

definitionGroups.group: (idiomatic, euphemistic) To have sexual intercourse (see sleep with).

examples: Oh, she didnt earn her promotion, she just slept her way to the top.
This caravan can sleep four people comfortably.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be careless, inattentive, or unconcerned; not to be vigilant; to live thoughtlessly.
(intransitive) To be dead; to lie in the grave.
(intransitive) To be, or appear to be, in repose; to be quiet; to be unemployed, unused, or unagitated; to rest; to lie dormant.
examples: a question sleeps for the present; the law sleeps

entries.meaning: (computing, intransitive) To wait for a period of time without performing any action.
examples: After a failed connection attempt, the program sleeps for 5 seconds before trying again.

entries.meaning: (computing, transitive) To place into a state of hibernation.
examples: Even when you have reasons not to sleep the computer, it's still a good idea to sleep the display after a period of time.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, mechanics, dynamics) To spin on its axis with no other perceptible motion.
examples: When a top is sleeping, it is spinning but not precessing.

entries.meaning: (transitive, mechanics, dynamics) To cause (a spinning top or yo-yo) to spin on its axis with no other perceptible motion.
examples: Yo-yo tricks involving sleeping the yo-yo (like "walking the dog" and "rocking the baby") cannot be performed in space.

description: From Middle English slepe, sleep, sleepe, from Old English slǣp (“sleep”), from Proto-West Germanic *slāp, from Proto-Germanic *slēpaz (“sleep”).

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The state of reduced consciousness during which a human or animal rests in a daily rhythm.
examples: We need to conduct an overnight sleep test to diagnose your sleep problem.

entries.meaning: (countable, informal) An act or instance of sleeping.
examples: I’m just going to have a quick sleep.
There are only three sleeps till Christmas!

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Rheum, crusty or gummy discharge found in the corner of the eyes after waking, whether real or a figurative objectification of sleep (in the sense of reduced consciousness).
examples: Synonyms: (informal) sleepy, (informal) sleeper, (informal) sleepy dust, (slang) crusty, (UK dialectal) gound
Wipe the sleep from your eyes.

entries.meaning: A state of plants, usually at night, when their leaflets approach each other and the flowers close and droop, or are covered by the folded leaves.
